am_sine_generator#

am_sine_generator(xmod, fs, fc, spl_level, print_m=False)[source]#

Amplitude-modulated sine wave generation

This function creates an amplitude-modulated (AM) signal with sinusoidal carrier of frequency â€˜fcâ€™, and arbitrary modulating signal â€˜xmodâ€™. The AM signal length is the same as the length of â€˜xmodâ€™. The signal level is adjusted to â€˜spl_levelâ€™ in dB.

Parameters:

  • xmod (array) â€“ Modulating signal, dim(N).

  • fs (float) â€“ Sampling frequency, in Hz.

  • fc (float) â€“ Carrier frequency, in Hz. Must be less than â€˜fs/2â€™.

  • spl_level (float) â€“ Sound Pressure Level [dB ref 20 uPa RMS] of the modulated signal.

  • print_m (bool, optional) â€“ Flag declaring whether to print the calculated modulation index. Default is False.

Returns:

  • y (numpy.array) â€“ Amplitude-modulated signal with sine carrier in Pascals, dim(N).

  • m (float) â€“ Modulation index

Warning

spl_level must be provided in dB, ref=2e-5 Pa.

See also

am_noise_generator

Amplitude modulation with broadband noise carrier

fm_sine_generator

Frequency modulation with sine wave carrier

sine_wave_generator

Sine wave generation

Notes

The modulation index â€˜mâ€™ will be equal to the peak value of the modulating signal â€˜xmodâ€™. Its value can be printed by setting the optional flag â€˜print_mâ€™ to True.

For â€˜mâ€™ = 0.5, the carrier amplitude varies by 50% above and below its unmodulated level. For â€˜mâ€™ = 1.0, it varies by 100%. With 100% modulation the wave amplitude sometimes reaches zero, and this represents full modulation. Increasing the modulating signal beyond that point is known as overmodulation.

Examples

>>> from mosqito.utils import am_sine_generator
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> import numpy as np
>>> fs = 48000      # [Hz]
>>> duration = 1
>>> t = np.linspace(0, duration, int(fs*duration))
>>> dB = 60         # [dB SPL]
>>> fc = 100        # [Hz]
>>> fm = 4          # [Hz]
>>> xmod = np.sin(2*np.pi*t*fm)
>>> y_am, m = am_sine_generator(xmod, fs, fc, dB, True)
>>> fig, plots = plt.subplots(2, 1)
>>> plots[0].set_title(f'Amplitude-modulated sine wave, modulation index = {m:.1f}')
>>> plots[0].plot(t, xmod, 'C0', label='Modulating signal')
>>> plots[0].legend(loc='upper right')
>>> plots[0].grid()
>>> plots[0].set_ylabel('Amplitude')
>>> plots[0].set_xlim([0, duration])
>>> plots[1].plot(t, y_am, '#69c3c5', label='AM signal')
>>> plots[1].legend(loc='upper right')
>>> plots[1].grid()
>>> plots[1].set_ylabel('Amplitude')
>>> plots[1].set_xlim([0, duration])
>>> plots[1].set_xlabel('Time [s]')
>>> fig.set_tight_layout('tight')
>>>
